verb.description: Lose or be deprived of (property or a right or privilege) as a penalty for wrongdoing.
examples: those unable to meet their taxes were liable to forfeit their property

noun.description: A fine or penalty for wrongdoing or for a breach of the rules in a club or game.

adjective.description: Lost or surrendered as a penalty for wrongdoing or neglect.
examples: the lands which he had acquired were automatically forfeit

origin: Middle English (originally denoting a crime or transgression, hence a fine): from Old French forfet, forfait, past participle of forfaire transgress, from for- out (from Latin foris outside) + faire do (from Latin facere).
